title: HSBC could see staff cuts amid a cost base adjustment and reorganization
text:
This story was delivered to Business Insider Intelligence Banking subscribers earlier this morning.

To get this story plus others to your inbox each day, hours before they're published on Business Insider, click here.

HSBC's Q3 2019 earnings reveal that adjusted profits before taxes fell 12% year-over-year (YoY) to $5.3 billion. The bank's results varied significantly between different regions: It saw strong performance in commercial banking in Hong Kong and the UK, as well as in retail banking in Hong Kong, despite current unrest in the region, HSBC interim group CEO Noel Quinn said in an earnings call. FILE PHOTO: HSBC logos are seen on a branch bank in the financial district in New York Reuters

But part of the bank's portfolio underperformed, such as its continental European business and its non-ring-fenced bank in the UK. Additionally, its US business put up an annualized return on tangible equity for the year-to-date of 1.9%, well below HSBC's 2020 goal of 6%.

Because of these shortcomings, the bank plans to allocate less capital to underperforming geographies and focus on higher-return opportunities, which Quinn says will require adjusting HSBC's cost base and remodeling its organizational structure.

We think this could potentially lead to more staff cuts: The bank has already announced reductions in the Middle East, North Africa, and Turkey, and it's shrinking its investment banking division as it turns away from underperforming segments.
